title: Fintechs defend bankers' failing grade on credit exam
text:
Mr Harding, who helped automate SME lending as chief risk officer at the Commonwealth Bank, said established lenders had plenty of skilled talent, but may allocate it towards coding algorithms rather than directly underwriting deals.

86400 chief risk officer Guy Harding helped automate SME lending at CBA. supplied

Yet he conceded that some big banks acted like "high street pawnbrokers" by over-relying on collateral, as opposed to the underlying strengths of a business, in their loan decisions.

The reactions among fintech companies to the credit exam finding amplified existing fissures within the start-up ecosystem.

Automation-based challenger banks such as 86400 tended to be more skeptical of Judo Bank's claim, as well as its broader pitch for an older, relationship-based lending model.

SME lender Moula, which specialises in algorithm-driven approaches to unsecured loans, declined to comment directly on the alleged skills deficit.

But co-founder Aris Allegos said he continued to hire people out of the big banks "because they respect first principles," and that teaching employees to innovate beyond this foundation required an "iterative process".

Advertisement

Judo Bank's strategy for overcoming the potential skills shortage includes an apprenticeship program, as well as more ambitious plans to assemble a "dad's army" of former bankers and to invest in artificial intelligence.

Mr Harding said many of the drivers for CBA to automate its SME lending such as the need to standardise decision-making, cut costs, and reduce waiting times remained significant challenges for older relationship-based models.

Meanwhile, other fintech start-ups who relied on manual lending processes were more sympathetic towards the challenge described by Judo Bank.

Capify, which relies on manual assessment on almost all of its loans to SMEs, said the low pass rate on the credit exam was "somewhat surprising" but that it likely owed to measurement against high standards.

"It sounds to me like [Judo Bank] is looking for something you don't normally get from the banks. And that makes sense: you need to get an edge," managing director John de Bree said.

Mr de Bree said that if there was a skill shortage, it would have a greater effect on Judo Bank, whose average loans were valued at $1.7 million. Capify averaged $40,000 per loan and processed most lending decisions within an hour.

"[Judo Bank] will need experienced people. Those skills aren't that easy," Mr de Bree said.
description: Chief risk officer for neobank 86400 said the finding was "more of an indictment of the interview process" used by Judo Bank.
